recordings.loc: Ireland (near  Whitehead), Mid and East Antrim, Northern Ireland
recordings.rmk: The sounds from this Goldfinch seem to amount to it being in two minds - 'sing or not to sing'?  I do not feel that there are any proper trills that would constitute proper song. Nonetheless, some of the  notes are quite beautiful - all the more so because they are not part of a longer composition.  The clip opens with 'chink' calls from a Chaffinch (at 0:03 and 0:05). A Song Thrush is often in the background (it can be heard at the very start and then regularly from 0:21). Finally the Goldfinch flies off - delivering its normal 'stickle-it' calls as it departs (from 1:08 for the next three seconds).

Two call types from a perched Goldfinch that flies away. In Swedish, the bird is named from its 'Stickle-it' flight call.  It reality, the call can be given at rest, just before the bird flies - or interjected between song bursts. The 'stickle-it' consists of a variable number of components, infrequently two, generally three but as many as five. On this clip, you can hear three-syllable 'stickle-it's at 0:01, five-syllables at 0:08, and four-syllables at 0:11.  Another trademark call is Goldfinch's whine. This is easier on the ear than than of a Greenfinch and sounds like a creaking swing (with the creaking sound down-slurring). Two good examples are at 0:03 and 0:05.
Song from a single bird with mimicry of Linnet (0:17.9) & Chaffinch (0:18.7) .

recordings.file-name: XC332073-Goldfinch song and juv calls 15 July 2016 0640.mp3
recordings.rmk: An adult Goldfinch singing (almost invisibly) from within the canopy of a 3m tall Sycamore tree. An unknown number of others were within earshot, some of which were juveniles. Nesting had occurred nearby and the birds were probably from the same family group.  Richness in Goldfinch song is based upon fairly similar phrases that are either shortened or lengthened or have the ending 'tweaked'. At times I hear a resemblance to the terminal flourish that often characteristic of Chaffinch song. This bird was uttering random 'tickle-it' flight calls, woven into the song's delivery - peppering song with an occasional flight call is typical of Goldfinch. Examples can be heard at 0:04, 0:07 and 0:19 Goldfinches make a scolding 'hissy rattle' in situations of aggression, such as defending a feeder port.  A fleeting example of the sound can be heard at 0:40. From 0:50 to the end, the lilting tittering of juveniles can be heard. Other calls from, I assume, the same birds are at XC332135.

recordings.loc: Serranía de Ronda (near  Ronda), Málaga, Andalucía

recordings.rmk: Flock
In flight
A few birds on thistles

When coming along a small way, a young European Goldfinch which seemed just had left its nest, fluttered towards me, climbed up my trousers and then fluttered from my bycicle to a hedge and the top of an apple tree. There it called and called. (►XC266536). Lateron in the evening the same situation, but now it called more powerfull (►XC266541). When we hided, we were glad to see adult Goldfinches contacting it.
